verses.text: Then I looked again at all the oppression that is done under the sun. Behold, the tears of the oppressed, and they have no one to comfort them! On the side of their oppressors there is power, but they have no one to comfort them.
verses.comment: Here, the Preacher mourns the injustice and suffering in the world, highlighting the loneliness and helplessness of the victims. This underscores a need for a righteous source of comfort and justice, ultimately pointing to the consolation and mercy that is only perfectly provided by God (cf. 2 Cor. 1:3-4).

verses.text: So I praised the dead who had already died more than the living who are still alive.
verses.comment: The Preacher’s extreme statement about the dead reflects the depth of his disillusionment about earthly life without justice. This foreshadows the longing for resurrection and eternal hope found in Christ (cf. 1 Thess. 4:13-14).

verses.text: But better than both is the one who has not yet been, who has not seen the evil work that is done under the sun.
verses.comment: Despair over evil leads the Preacher to say it’s better never to have existed. This passage points to humanity’s longing for justice and peace, ultimately fulfilled not in this world but in the kingdom of God that Christ brings (Rom. 8:18-23).

verses.text: Then I saw that all toil and every skillful work spring from a man’s rivalry with his neighbor. This also is vanity and a chasing after wind.
verses.comment: Human ambition is often fueled by envy, leading only to emptiness. The teaching here challenges the believer to detach from pride and rivalry, reflecting the virtue of humility taught throughout Scripture (cf. Phil. 2:3-4).

verses.text: The fool folds his hands and consumes his own flesh.
verses.comment: Laziness leads to ruin just as surely as envy leads to rivalry. True wisdom seeks a balanced, disciplined life, in harmony with God’s design (Prov. 19:15).

verses.text: Better is a handful with quietness than two handfuls with toil and chasing after the wind.
verses.comment: Contentment is better than endless striving. The value of interior peace and moderation is affirmed—a principle seen throughout Christian spirituality (1 Tim. 6:6).

verses.text: Again, I saw vanity under the sun:
verses.comment: The Preacher continues, exploring the futility found in earthly life apart from God. This repeated observation sets the stage for yearning for something lasting and meaningful, fulfilled ultimately in following Christ (John 6:27).

verses.text: There is one who is alone, without a second. He has neither son nor brother, yet there is no end to all his toil, and his eyes are never satisfied with riches—he never asks, 'For whom am I toiling and depriving myself of pleasure?' This also is vanity and a miserable business.
verses.comment: Solitude and greed leave man empty even if he gains much. This anticipates Christ’s teaching that true treasure is found in self-giving and communion with others (cf. Mark 12:31).

verses.text: Two are better than one, because they have a good reward for their labor.
verses.comment: Scripture emphasizes the importance of relationships and unity, echoing the creation of mankind for companionship (Gen. 2:18). The principle of collaboration prefigures the unity desired among believers (John 17:21).

verses.text: For if they fall, one will lift up his companion. But woe to him who is alone when he falls and has not another to lift him up.
verses.comment: Mutual support is a gift from God. Christians are called to bear each other’s burdens, a key aspect of living out the faith in the one body of Christ (1 Cor. 12:25-27).

verses.text: Again, if two lie together, they keep warm, but how can one keep warm alone?
verses.comment: The practical imagery highlights the benefits of fellowship, which not only meets physical needs but reflects spiritual warmth found in true unity and charity.

verses.text: Though one may prevail against another, two will withstand him. A threefold cord is not quickly broken.
verses.comment: This points to the strength of community and, spiritually, can allude to the completeness of unity in divine love. Some see a hint here of the New Testament teaching that where believers gather together in Christ’s name, God is present among them (Matt. 18:20).

verses.text: Better is a poor and wise youth than an old and foolish king who no longer knows how to take advice.
verses.comment: Wisdom is more valuable than status or age. Humility and the willingness to receive instruction are vital for leaders and all God’s people (Prov. 12:15).

verses.text: For out of prison he came to reign, though in his own kingdom he was born poor.
verses.comment: This can recall the stories of Joseph and David, rising from humble beginnings to leadership. Spiritual application: God often chooses the lowly to confound the proud (Luke 1:52), a pattern fulfilled perfectly in Christ.

verses.text: I saw all the living who walk under the sun follow the youth, the successor, who stands in his place.
verses.comment: The fleeting allegiance of people to new leaders shows the instability of worldly acclaim. True continuity and faithfulness, as the Church teaches, are found only in God’s established order and guidance.

verses.text: There was no end to all the people, to all whom he led. Yet those who come later will not rejoice in him. Surely this also is vanity and a chasing after wind.
verses.comment: Fame and influence are ultimately temporary and unsatisfying. This reiterates the vanity of worldly pursuits and subtly points to the importance of seeking something eternal—namely, participation in the unbroken unity and faithfulness found in the true body of Christ.
